description: From Anglo-Norman prevaricassion, Middle French prevarication, and their source, Latin praevāricātiō (“collusion with an opponent; transgression; deceit”), from the stem of praevāricor.

entries.meaning: (now rare) Deviation from what is right or correct.

examples: Prevarication became the order of the day in his government while truth was a stranger in those halls.

entries.meaning: A secret abuse in the exercise of a public office.
(Ancient Rome, law, historical) The collusion of an informer with the defendant, for the purpose of making a sham prosecution.
(law) A false or deceitful seeming to undertake a thing for the purpose of defeating or destroying it.
